text: ee LOCOANUTS
We want to see you, Mr. Hammer.
What's the matter? Somebody pay their bill? BOYS’ We want our money.
Yes -- money -- you want your money?
We want to get paid.
Oh -- you want MY money? Is that fair? Do I want your money? Suppose George Washington's soldiers had asked for money? Where would this country be today?
But they did ask.
And where's Washington? No, my friends -~ no ~- money will never make you happy -~ and happy will never make you money. That might be a wise crack, but I doubt it.
We want our money!

T'll make you all a promise, If you'll all stick with me and work hard, we'll forget about money. Let's get together and we'll make a@ regular hotel out of this place! I'll put writing paper in the hotel and next year if you behave your- selves, we'll have envelopes. I'm
de

id HAMMER (Cont'd) going to put extra blankets in all your rooms -- free. There'll be no cover charge. Think -= think of the opportunities here in Florida. Three years ago I came to Florida without a nickel in my pocket. And now I've got a nickel in my pocket.
That's all very well, Mr. Hammer, but we haven't been paid in two weeks and we want our wages.
Wages? Do you want to be wage slaves? Answer me that! . Boys No!

Of course not. Well, what makes Wage slaves? Wages, I want you to be free. Remember there's no~ thing like Liberty, except Colliers and the Saturday Evening Post. Be free, my friends. One for. all and all for me -- me for you and three for five and six for a quarter!
Pardon me, a couple of telegrams for you, Mr. Hammer.

There you see. Business is begin- ning to pick up already. Now if you boys will only be calm -- ha (reads) "We arrive this afternoon on the four-thirty. Kindly reserve two floors and three ceilings," They mast be mice! (continues reading) "If we like your property, we will immediately buy." See that —— things are starting our Way, al- ready. Who is it from -- Western Union and they've got a lot of money too. On the four-thirty, eh? I'17 take a bus down myself,
Here's another one, Mr. Hammer.
dn
~~ oN

Say, we're going to be swamped, By tonight, we're going to turn away thousands of people. reads "If there 1s another hotel in Cocoanut Beach, cancel ovr re- servations." I lmow itl It was too good, Wait a minute! (continues reading) "P.S. Aunt Fanny had an elight- pound boy. Can you come to the wedding?" You see, everything is all right, boys -- everything is all.right. You are all invited to the wedding of aunt Fanny's eight- pound boy. .
Hooray!

Oh, but that won't be for a couple of years yet! In the meantime, I want you to buck up -- get down to work, Let's put this thing over with a bang and above all -— forget about money. Don't think of itl! Just forget about it, be- cause you won't get it anyway. Boys (dancing) Hooray! Horray! Hooray!

See that. I keep them dancing for their money! Yeah, Jamison, I'm going down to meet the 4:15. If I never get back, you'll know I'm Still waiting for the train, and in my absence, I'm relying upon you to take good care of everything.
You can depend upon me,
That's fine. And think of me.
You bet I will.
And if any guests come in -- take good care of them. And remember I'll be back some day, Keep a light burning in the window -. if you can find a window, Good-bye, Jamison,
Hello, Bobby, Why so downhearted? Bob Adams cut you out with Polly Potter?
I'm not worried about a hotel clerk.
No, but I'll bet you're worried about the Potter millions. You Generally could use money in the old days --.
Oh lay off that stuff.
~~ You know marrying Polly is the Only way for you to square your debts, .
T can take care of myself.
I doubt it. Suppose I have a little Plan to take care of both of us. What do you mean?
Have you ever seen that diamond necklace of Mrs. Potter's?
You bet I have. What's that got to do with us?
Her room and mine are right next to each other. Hers is three-eighteen; mine three-twenty. The door between is unlocked.
Well?
She keeps everything in a jewel case, locked up in her dresser. The key is always in her bag. That's what you have got to get.
It's a large order, but maybe it san be done, Suppose I invite Mrs, Potter and Polly to take supper with me tonight?
What then?
Some time during the evening I might be able to get the key out of her bag.
Now you're talking. That sounds more like old times and now I will _ try and get rid of Bob Adams for you,
ap
Look, this is Cocoanut Manor. You know that hill ---?
What a question. Do I know that cunning little hill?
It's cunning, all right. That's why there hasn't been any develop- ment here,
Couldn't it be cut down?

No =- it's too expensive. Now, here's what happened. John W. Berryman was here to see it last month. You know Berryman practi- Cally made Palm Beach and Miami, but he said he wouldn't touch this. Now when a man like that passes a place up, no one wants it, Do you know anything about architecture?
No, but I'd love to learn.

Well, I made a drawing of the whole Place, showing it as a built up scheme, without cutting down the hill, or having it get in the way. T made the hill fit in with the architectural scheme, see? I sent Berryman a copy last week, and his Secretary wrote me a nice note Saying they were studying my plans.
That's thrilling! Does Mr. Hammer know about it?
I did. But if he takes it, I will design the buildings. Say, I may be an architect yet.
If he only does, I'm sure it will be the most beautiful Place in the world.
ap
Well, it would be if you livea there? Look, see what I've written? Heaven for Polly and me.
That looks great. When do I move in?
Any day now.
It's a lovely @ream, Bob. Let's make it come true.

The skies are always blue, When my dreams come true, And I'll be smiling thru When my dreams come true, That Spanish castle -- I built in my mind Will be a love nest -- the practi- cal kind . And I'll be there -- with you When my dreams come true.
Ever since I met you All that I seem to do is dream.

Wonderful dreams -- Heaven's before my eyes -- When will I realize my dreams -- Wonderful dreams -- The skies will all be blue When my dreams come true, And I'll be smiling thru, When my dreams come true, That Spanish castle -- I built in my mind Will be a love nest -- the practi- cal kind And I'll be there -- with you When my dreams come true.
Will you look at that?
I am looking.
, fm
He EXITS,
Well, it's darn cute. I wonder who it can be.
Let's find out.
Then little Red Riding Hood said to the wolf -~ wolf-wolf-wolfwolf-wolf, Hello.
How do you do, Miss Potter.
Hello,

Your mother is looking for you, Miss Potter? POLLY . She generally is, and she generally finds me. You know Mother. Thanks @ lot. It was a lovely story, Mr. Adams, I'd like to hear the rest of it sometime, good-bye.
I wonder if I could hear it some~ time.
With pleasure. How about you, Yates?
No thanks. You know what happens to bad little boys who tell stories.
Certainly, they marry the beautiful princess. So long. But I'il be there with you, when my dreams come true.
Nice boy. The kind who usually gets what he wants,
Not always. I might win out yet.
‘ge REEL II
Well -- miracles do happen.
Well, Polly, you've been out again with Mr. Adams,
But only for a little while, Mother.
Why a daughter of mine should fool around with a hotel clerk when she has the opportunity of marrying one of the Boston Yates -- is more than I can understand.
Oh, who cares, about the Boston Yates? Anyway, Bob isn't a clerk; he's an architect. He's only elerking until he can get started.
One who clerks, Polly, 1s a clerk, and that settles it. And I want . you to remember that no Potter has ever been involved in a single scandal.
How about Uncle Dick?
Polly, it's a well known fact that your uncle was drunk at the time, ‘and another thing, young lady, I'm quite tired of your sitting on the beach all hours of the night.
Hey! Hey' Why don't you try something for that insomnia? You oughta cut out drinking so much coffee.
I'm sorry, sir, say, any luck with the 4:309
ge
Yes, it didn't hit me, that's the only luck I had with it,
Mr, Hammer, I think I know what's wrong with the hotel.
I think I know too. You're fired. Get your hat and my coat and get out.
Maybe the season hasn't started yet. Maybe the hotel hasn't opened. Don't worry, Mr. Hammer, in a few weeks you'll be cleaning up.
Yes, and making the beds! Go on, get out -- I can handle the rush myself,
How do you do, sir?

Why don't you whistle at the cross- ing? You're just the woman I'm looking for. And now whether you like it or not, I'm going to tell you all about Florida real estate. It is the first time it has ever been mentioned here -- today.
I'm sorry, Mr. Hammer, but I'm | afraid ---

Do you know that property values have increased since 1929 one thousand per cent? Do you know that this is the biggest development since Sophie Tucker? De you know that Florida is the show spot of America and Cocoanut Manor the black spot of Plorida?
You told me about that yesterday.
ge
il

I know but I left out a comma. Look, in a little while I'm going to hold an auction sale at Cocoanut Manor, the suburb terrible or beauti- ful. You must come over. There's going to be entertainment, sand- wiches, and the auction. If you don't like auctions, we can play contract. Here it is -- Cocoanut Manor -~ 42 hours from Times Square by railroad. 1600 miles as the crow flies and 1800 miles as the horse flies. There you are -~ Cocoanut Manor glorifying the American sewer and the Florida sucker. It's the most exclusive residential district in Florida. Nobody lives there. And the climate ~~ ask me about the climate, I dare you. .
Very well -- how is the ---
I'm glad you brought it up. Our motto is Cocoanut Beach, no snow, no ice, and no business. Do you know that Florida is the greatest state in the Union?
It 18?
Take its climate -- no, we took that -- take its fruits -- take the alligator pears -- take all the alligator pears and keep ‘em -- see if I care. Do you know how alligator pears are made?
Haven't the slightest idea ---

There you are. That's because you've never been an alligator, and don't let it happen again. Do you know that it sometimes requres years ‘to bring the pear and the alligator together? They don't like each other.
ec
No.
No. Do you know how many alligator pears are sent out of this state every year and told not to come back?
I don't think I do.
All they can get a hold of, Florida feeds the nation but nobody feeds me and that's what I want to talk to you about.
Mr. Hammer --~
-- another thing, take our cattle raising. Oh, I don't mean anything personal. But here is the ideal Cattle raising section. We have long horns, short horns and the shoe horns.
Mr. Hammer, will you let me say something, please....
I hardly think s0, and there's something else I want to bring to your mind. Where will you be when you're sixty-five? That's only about three months from now.
If I were to buy, I should prefer some place like Palm Beach.
Palm Beach? The Atlantic City of yesterday? The slums of tomorrow? Do you know that the Population of Cocoanut Beach has doubled in the past week?
Has it?
ge
Three bulldogs were born and we're expecting a nanny goat in the morning.
I'm sorry, but I'm afraid I must be going.

Aw, now, don't go. Before you go, let me show you a sample of the sewer pipe we're going to lay. Look at it. Nobody could fool you on a sewer pipe, can they, a woman like you? Now this is an eight inch pipe. But of course, all property owners will be allowed to vote on the size of their pipe. In case of a tie, it goes to the Supreme Court, and I can give you a@ little inside information in advance. The chief justice is crazy about his type of sewer. Here put it in your pocket -- see you later.
Mr. Hammer, I can't use this. I Gon't want it.
mr Reel IIft 14

Hello. Yes, ice water in 318? Is that so? Where did you get it? Oh, you want some? Oh, that's different. Have you got any ice? No, I haven't. This is Cocoanut Beach. No snow. No ice. Get some onions, they will make your eyes water. What? You, too.
Oh, Mr. Hammer, Mrs. Thompson wants to know if you'd reserve a table for her in a nice quiet spot.

Yeh. A nice quiet spot, eh? Yeh. Tell her she can eat in the lobby. Say, we ought to dress this place up a bit, it looks terrible. Front. Front. Front. Here front. Here front. Here front. Front. Front. Jameson, what's become of our front? Are we all out of front? I'm going to fire some of these people; give me the fire bell. Hey you, stick around here; now if any customers come in tie ‘em and brand 'em. Look at him. He's better dressed than I am.
Hey. Come on. Come on.
Gentlemen, how. do you do? Come here. Come here. What are you boys giving me, the run around? Come over here. Now, what do you want? What do you want? Explain your business. :
We send you telegrams.
Oh, you're the boys that sent these telegrams?
How do you do?
That's a coincidence. I used to send telegrams myself.
we mr Reel III
How are you?
And how are you? That's all right. Don't worry,
Say, you can stay, but you will have to take that ground hog out of here. Now what do you want? Explain your business.
Well, we want to make a reservash.
Reservash?
Yes. We want a room, but no bath.
Oh, I see. You're just here for the winter. Well step this way and I'll see what I can do for you.
All right. We stay for the summer, too.
I'm sorry boys, but we got no vacancies.
Gota no vacancies?
We got plenty of rooms.
Thatsa awright, we take a room.
You want a room?
All right, we take a vacancy.
Boy, take the gentlemen's baggage. Hey, hey, do you know that suitcase is empty?
ph
That's all right. Wetll fill it up before we leave.

Oh, you will, eh? Well, you will empty it before I go out. Step right this way boys. Put on your moniker. This boy wins the gold cigar. Anybody else? Right this way. Hey, hey, hey, don't throw that. That's only for long distance. Now then what do you want? Would you like a suite on the third floor?
No, I'll take a Polock in the base- “ment.
You'll have to take that up with the Commissary Department, that's an entirely different propositon and I can't -.-~ :
Here you are. Let me help you here. I'm sorry. I'm sorry. The after- noon mail isn't in yet. I can use you the first of the month.
Telegram for Mr. Hammer.
Telegram? Just tell them I'll send them the money in the morning. Now then, what do you want? What do you want? Do you want a single room?
We'd like to double up.

Well, eat some green apples. What's that? You'll have to talk louder. IT can't hear you. If you'll take your nose aut of that receiver, it will be okay. Ha-ha-ha. Funny feller you. Hello. What's that? You want to know where you can get hold of Mrs. Potter. I don't know, she is awfully ticklish. Now I'm in a position gentlemen ----
ph
He's hungry.

Here, have one of these flowers. They're Buckwheat. Pick out a nice One, now, I don't want you to get any the worst of this. I'm so glad. Now you boys will pardon me for a few minutes. I have some very in- portant business to attend to. As a matter of face, I'm going upstairs to get your partner a stomach pump. He needs one. And I'll be down in a few minutes. And while I'm gone, don't forget -- register.
Hey, don't forget -- register. That's all right. Hello. Hello. No, we got no rooms. We gotta nothing. We gotta no customers. All right. All right. I send you up some. All right. Good-bye.
Did you ring sir?
Did you ring sir?
Did you ring sir?
Come on. All right then, but let's be careful.
I will.
Tell me how it is that the door between your room and Mrs. Potter's is open?
Well, you see, I told her that I trusted her.
You trusted her? (laughter)
Hey, stop that.
ph
Come on, let's dance.
Come on, Penelope, let's get away from this bum.
Bum. Bum. Bum! Bum! Bum! Trala Boom, etc.
I could kill those tramps.
Wait a minute. Don't kill them yet. I've got an idea.
About them?
Umhuh. Listen, when the necklace is found missing someone has got to be blamed. Why not them?
Gee, that's not bad. But have you got anything definite?
Suppose I flirt with them and they come to my room. :
What then?
I'll complain to the management. Then on the night the necklace disappeared they were seen near Mrs. Potter's room. Get it? e
You bet. I get it. That's a grand idea.
Thanks, kind sir. Well, I've got to run along now. See you later? Good-bye,
ph REEL III

Hey, hey, what you do, eh? All the time you eat. That's no good. We gotta get the money. Right now, I'd do anything for money. I kill some- body for money. I~a-keel you for money. Oh, no, you're my friend. I keel you for nothing. What do you laugh for? You're in the hotel three hours and you no got something yet. What you steal? A watch? Thatsa fine, Gingersolla watch. Thatsa fine. Thats all you steal?
Hey, I think I know your face,
I give up, whose is it?
I'11 tell you in a minute. I brought some pictures from head- quarters, Let me see your face. Yours too.
All right. All right. I make my own face. Thisa way. No pushing. Hey. Come one. Your start!
What are you guys fighting for?
We no fight. That's my friend. We Play this way.

Wat're you doing around here? What's your name? I'm pretty suspicious of you birds, Now you listen to me, I haven't anything on you yet, but I'm going to keep watching. I've got your full records right here in ny pocket. There's enough to send you up the minute you start anything. Do you get me?
Wise Guy! Wise Guy! Gotta start a fight when the detective comes around, can't waita little, but you goota pusha,
Hurry along, my dear, Only a few minutes to get to the train, Can you tell me what's the next train to Philadelphia?
There's a train once a week and sometimes twice a day.
Thank you.
That's all right.
A little tight. Needs something taken out. That's -- just what I need. Thanks.
Hello.
How do you do?
That's a good lcoking coat you have on.
You like it, eh? PENELOPE . Do you know, you look like the _ Prince of Wales,
Better,
Where did you get that coat?
Thatsa my coat.
That's your coat?
That's my coat. PENELOPE. Well, it doesn't fit you. cHICco I kmow I had it made to order. PENELOPE. Tell me, what are you doing tonight?
Maybe you gotta good idea, eh?
Well, don't you dare come to. 320 at 11 o'clock.
All right, I come half past ten.
mm
(to Harpo) Did you see a handkerchief? I thought I dropped one. Well, it really doesn't matter because what I'm really interested in is you. Harpo toots his horn.

Did anyone ever tell you that you looked like the Prince of Wales? (nods yes) That's funny, I thought it was an original idea of mine. Tell me, do you know who I am? Do you know my room number? Well, I'll be there at eleven o'clock tonight.

Did anyone ever tell you that you look like the Prince of Wales? I don't mean the present Prince of Wales; one of the old Wales, and believe me I say Wales, I mean Wales. I know a whale when I see one. Did you say your room is three eighteen? You know I am the proprietor of this hotel and I have a passkey for every room in it.
Passkey?

Passkey -- that's Russian for pass ~- you know they passkey down the streetskey. Won't you like down? Aw, if we could find a little bungalow -- eh? ‘Oh, of course, I know where we could find one, but maybe the people wouldn't get out. But if we could find a nice little empty bungalow just for me and you, where we could bill and cow, no -- I meant we could bull and cow.
Do you know what you are trying to say? HAMMER “ Yes, 1t is not what I'm thinking of. What I meant was, if we had a nice
mm

23 HAMMER (Cont'd) little bungalow and you was on the inside and I was on the outside trying to get in and me inside rying to get out or. no- vou'n inside out and I was upside ~- fray tell you, if you don't hear from me by next Friday, the whole thing's off!
I don't think I understand.
I mean -- your eyes -- your eyes, they shine like the pants of a blue serge suit-
What? The very idea. That's an insult.

That's not a reflection on you -- it's on the pants. What I meant was if we had a nice bungalow and I came home from work -- and you standing by the gate -- no -- you'd come home from work -~ and I was standing by the gate, and we came down the path and we went inside and the shades were drawn and the lights were low, and then -- are you sure your husband's dead?
Why, yes.

There seems to be a trace of un- certainty in that "yes." You know ayes like that was once responsible for me jumping out of a window and I'm not the Jumper I used to be. What I meant was, you are going to be here all winter and I'm stuck with the hotel anyhow -~ why don't you grab me until you can make ather arrangements?
My dear, Mr. Hammer, I shall never get married before my daughter.
You did once! Oh, but I love you, I love you. Can't you see how I am pining for you.
* am
What in the world is the matter with you?
Oh, I'm not myself tonight. I don't know who I am. One false move and I'm yours. I love you, I love you anyhow, .
I don't think you'd love me if I were poor.
I might, but I'd keep my mouth shut,
I'll not stay here any longer and be insulted this way!
_No -- don't go away and leave me here alone. You stay here and T'll go away.
I don't know what to say.
Oh say, that you'll be truly mine, or truly yours, or yours truly. Don't you know what I'm ---
Will you keep your hands to yourself.

Come on, I'll play you one more game. Come on the 3 af you. Oh, can you come down a little bit. Just think -- tonight, tonight when the moon is sneaking around the clouds I'll be sneaking around you. I'1l meet you tonight under the moon. Oh, I can see you now ~- you and the moon, You wear a neck- tie so I'11 kmow you. (HARP SOLO BY HARPO MARX)
ph REEL V : 25
Send up some ice water right away. That's right. Thank you. Thank goodness. HARVEY . Close the door.
Did you get the key?
Yes, it's one of these.
Oh, that's fine, Now, listen. We can't take any chances on this job.
How do you mean?
There's bound to be trouble when she misses the necklace.
Well?
We don't want it found on us.
I should say not.
We've got to play safe and hide it somewhere, for a while.
Hide it?
Just for a few days.
Yes -- but where?
Anywhere but in here.
Hide 1t? I know just the place. A hollow tree stump about a mile from here. Will that do?  rr
Fine -- but how do I get there?
It's the Cocoanut Manor. You've been out there?
I'm not so sure, Harvey.

Here, I'11 show you. “Now you go right out éocoanut Road; then there's Augustine Road, like this -- but in- stead, you take the Granada Road. Suddenly you come to a clearing with a fringe of trees around it. That's Cocoanut Manor, where the stump is. It's about twenty feet from the edge of the clearing. That's where you put the jewels. You can't miss it. Now, you take the necklace right out there, see? I've got to go back down stairs, or Mrs. Potter will be suspicious. And be careful!
I will -- Cocoanut Manor -- Granada Road -~~- Twenty feet from the clear- ing ~- everything's going along swim- mingly now.
Do you remember me? The Prince of Wales?
Why, yes, of course I do, but -- Mr. Hammer, how dare you come into my room?
See here, 1f there's going to be two People in this room, it will be fifty cents extra.
Did he go?
Who?
Anybody.
“age rr
Get out. Oh, Prince -= how you frightened me.
Ha ha ha ha ha.
This hotel not only has running water; it has running guests.
You remember me? Prince of Wales?
Who is it?
Me -- King of England.
My father!
Ha ha ha ha.
Come in.
Ice water.
Put it there -- thank you.
"Thank you?" Why didn’t you give'm a dime?
Come in.
Lay down.
Well -- I never! I should say not! You get out of here! Get out! Hurry! Hurry! My -- Come in! What is the
: rr
28 MRS. POTTER (Cont'd) matter with that man? Mr. Hammer, what are you doing in my room? Don't you dare take that coat off in this room!
Well -~ I was on --~
-- You get out of here as fast as you can go!
I was only playing, that's ail!
I'll find out about this outfit. Thank goodness, he's gone. Never mind, operator! Come -- come in -- who are you?
That's all right. I'll be through in a minute. Well, I guess there's nobody in here.
You don't know where to look.
Ah -- what's that you said?
Oh, this 1s awful. When you've quite finished, let me know.
Well, everything seems to be all right in here.
I'm not so sure about that,
All right. I know where to go.
W-h-e-w! Alone at last. Oh!  fm REEL V ; 29

Come over here, I want to see you. Now, listen to me. I'm not going to have. that red-headed fellow run- ning around the lobby. If you want to keep him up in the room, you'll have to keep him in a trap.
You can't catch him.
Who is he?
He's my partner, but he no speak.

Oh, that's your silent partner. Well, anyhow you wired me about some property. I've thought it over. Now, I can let you have three lots water- ing the front, or I can let you have three lots fronting the water. Now, these lots cost me nine thousand dollars and I'm going to let you have them for fifteen because I like you.
Ino buy nothing. I gotta no money.
You got no money?
I no gotta one cent.
How're you going to pay for your room?
Thatsa your lookout.
Oh, you're just an idle rumor?
Well, you see, we comma here to maka money. I reada in de paper, and it say: "Big boom in Florida.” So we come. We're coupla big booms, too!
Well, I'll show you how you can make some REAL money. I'm going te hold an auction in a little while in Cocoanut Manor. You -- you know what an auction is, eh?
I come from Italy on the Atlantic- Auction. :

Well, let's go ahead as if nothing happened. I say I'm holding an auction at Cocoanut Manor. And when the crowd gathers around, I want you to mingle with them. Don't pick their pockets, Just mingle with them -- and -~-- ,
I'll find time for both.
Well, maybe we .can cut out the auction. Here's what I mean. If somebody says a@ hundred dollars, you say two -~ if somebody says two hundred dollars, you say three --- .
Speaka up?
That's right. Now, if nobody says anything, then you start it off.
How'm I goning to know when to no say nuthin'? .
Well, they'll probably notify you. You fool, if they don't say anything, you'll hear ‘em, won't you?
Well, mebbe I no lissen.
Well, don't tell ‘em. Now then, if we're successful in disposing of these lots, I'll see that you get a nice commission.
How about some money?
rr
Well, you can have your choice. Now, in arranging these lots, of course, we use blue prints. You know what a blue print is, huh?
How is it that you never got double pneumonia?
I go around by myself.
Do you know what a lot is?
Yeah, too much.
I don't mean a whole lot. Just a little lot with nothing on it.

Any time ynu gotta too much, you gotta whole lot. Look, I'll explain it to you. Some time you no gotta much; sometimes you gotta whole lot. You know that it's a lat. Somebady else maybe thinka its too much; it's a whole lot, too. Now, a whole lot is too much; too much is a whole lot; same thing.

Say, the next time I see you, remind me not to talk to you, will you? Come here, Rand McNally, and I'12 explain this thing to you. Now look, this is a@ map and diagram of the whole cocoanut section. This whole area is within a radius of approximately three-quarters ora mile, Radius? Is there a remote Possibility that you know what a radius means?
It'sa WJZ.
rr
Well -- I walked right into that one. It's going to be a cinch explaining the rest of this thing to you -- I can see that.
I catcha on quick.

That's a rodeo you're thinking of. Look, Einstein. Here's Cocoanut ‘Manor. No matter what you say, this is Cocoanut Manor. Here's Cocoanut Manor. Here's Cocoanut Heights. That's a.swamp -- right over where the -- where the road forks, that's Cocoanut Junction.
Where have you got Cocoanut Custard?

Why, that's on one of the forks. You probably eat with your knife, so you wouldn't have to worry about that. Now, here's the main road, leading out of Cocoanut Manor.
